com.hazelcast.jet.server

Class JetBootstrap

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.hazelcast.jet.server.JetBootstrap

  • public final class JetBootstrap
extends Object
    A helper class that allows one to create a standalone runnable JAR which contains all the code needed to submit a job to a running Jet cluster. The main issue with achieving this is that the JAR must be attached as a resource to the job being submitted, so the Jet cluster will be able to load and use its classes. However, from within a running main() method it is not trivial to find out the filename of the JAR containing it.

    This helper is a part of the solution to the above "bootstrapping" issue. To use it, follow these steps:

    1. Write your main() method and your Jet code the usual way, except for calling getInstance() to acquire a Jet client instance (instead of Jet.newJetClient()).
    2. Create a runnable JAR with your entry point declared as the Main-Class in MANIFEST.MF.
    3. Run your JAR, but instead of java -jar jetjob.jar use jet.sh submit jetjob.jar. The script is found in the Jet distribution zipfile, in the bin directory. On Windows use jet.bat.
    4. The Jet client will be configured from hazelcast-client.xml found in the config directory in Jet's distribution directory structure. Adjust that file to suit your needs.

    For example, write a class like this: 

     public class CustomJetJob {
   public static void main(String[] args) {
     JetInstance jet = JetBootstrap.getInstance();
     jet.newJob(buildDag()).execute().get();
   }

   public static DAG buildDag() {
       // ...
   }
 }

    After building the JAR, submit the job: 

     $ jet.sh submit jetjob.jar
    Since:
    3.0

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static JetInstance getInstance()
      Returns the bootstrapped JetInstance.

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static JetInstance getInstance()
        Returns the bootstrapped JetInstance. The instance will be automatically shut down once the main() method of the JAR returns.
